title: Japanese trade minister resigns after he was caught giving gifts to voters
text:
Japan's trade minister resigned Friday a month into his job in a scandal over condolence money, expensive melons and other gifts allegedly offered to voters.

Isshu Sugawara offered his resignation after a newspaper published what it claimed was a photo of him offering a condolence payment of 20,000 Japanese yen (£145) to the family of a person who had died in his district.

While such gifts - known as 'incense payments' - are common in Japan after a death, the money violates election laws which prohibit offering voters gifts whether an election is taking place or not.

Isshu Sugawara offered his resignation just a month after becoming Japanese trade minister after he was caught offering gifts to people in his Tokyo district

Shukan Bunshun also detailed claims that Sugawara offered melons, crabs, cod roe, flowers, oranges and other items as gifts, often accompanied by signed cards.

'I bear responsibility for his appointment and I apologize to the people for causing a situation like this,' Prime Minister Shinzo Abe told reporters.

Abe said Sugawara tendered his resignation because he did not want to hold up important discussions in Parliament over his scandal.

Sugawara's resignation comes just weeks after Abe added him to the Cabinet in a reshuffling prompted by the July election, in which his ruling coalition secured a comfortable majority.

Sugawara denied paying cash to voters but has flip-flopped on other details.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe accepted the resignation and promoted Hiroshi Kajiyama (left) in Sugawara's place

He told reporters he regretted he had to step down in the middle of his term and leave work unfinished.

He said the condolence money was presented to supporters by his aide, and that he will fully investigate and clarify.

Abe took office in December 2012 and is set to be the longest serving prime minister in Japanese postwar history next month.

He has managed to shake off various scandals, partly because of an opposition that is divided and unpopular.
description: Japan's trade minister Isshu Sugawara resigned from his post Friday just a month into the job after he was caught giving gifts to voters in his district including oranges and flowers.
